CAS Key Laboratory of Low-Carbon Conversion Science and Engineering, Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences Shanghai 201210 PR China The influence of impregnation sequences on the structure and performance of the Ru-based catalysts for olefins synthesis from syngas via Fischer-Tropsch reaction (FTO) was investigated. Among the catalysts studied, Na-Ru/SiO2 (Na was impregnated before Ru) exhibited the highest CO conversion (43.5 %) and olefins yield (33.9 %). In contrast, Ru-Na/SiO2 (Ru was impregnated before Na) showed the lowest CO conversion (26.6 %) and olefins yield (19.8 %). Characterization analysis indicated that Na-Ru/SiO2 exhibited higher Ru dispersion. In addition, the structural configuration of Na-Ru/SiO2 was found to enhance CO adsorption capabilities to create a C*-rich localized chemical environment, thereby increasing catalytic activity and olefins production. This study demonstrates a straightforward and effective approach to optimize Ru utilization for the design of Ru-based FTO catalysts. Graphical Abstract Keywords Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Impregnation sequences Ru nanoparticles Dispersion CO adsorption and dissociation Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Catalyst preparation methods play a key role in heterogeneous catalytic reactions. Among the reported methods, impregnation is one of the most widely applied techniques, mainly involving the immersion of a solution containing one or more metal salts into a highly porous support material [1]. Impregnation can be further divided into co-impregnation and sequential impregnation [2]. Co-impregnation involves mixing solutions containing at least two active components and immersing them in support. In contrast, sequential impregnation involves an initial application of a metal salt solution to the porous support to anchor the metal component, followed by immersion in a solution containing an additional metal species [3]. It has been reported that altering the impregnation sequence can change the surface structure of the catalyst, which may affect the interactions and dispersion between different components, thereby influencing catalytic performance [4–6]. For example, Gnanamani et al. investigated the impact of the order of adding phosphorus and cobalt to SiO2 on Fischer-Tropsch synthesis activity and product selectivity [7]. They found that P-modified SiO2-supported cobalt catalysts exhibited higher activity and C5+ selectivity, suggesting that P modification of SiO2 may enhance Fischer-Tropsch activity by altering the interaction at the surface between cobalt and hydroxyl groups on SiO2. Braga et al. employed both co-impregnation and sequential impregnation to load CuO and Nb2O5 onto SiO2-Al2O3. It was found that CuO had a significant effect on the crystallinity of Nb2O5 [8]. The interaction between CuO and Nb2O5 occurs not only on the surface hydroxyl groups of the SiO2-Al2O3 support, but also on the surface hydroxyl groups of the niobium pentoxide. Osakoo et al. found that in the Pd-Co/SBA-15 catalyst, the Co3O4 nanoparticles in the co-impregnated samples were notably larger, while the sequential impregnation samples possessed higher and more stable CO conversion rates along with greater C5–9 selectivity [9]. Jing et al. investigated the impact of the impregnation order of metal precursors on the interactions among Ni, Co, and MgO, leading to significant differences in CO2 adsorption capacities [10]. Uner D.O. et al. investigated the effects of sequential and co-impregnation methods on hydrogen promotion in Ru catalysts, finding that K addition reduced the amount of hydrogen adsorbed on the metal (site blocking) and the number of hydroxyl groups on the support [11]. During catalyst preparation, K was incorporated into the support through exchange with Si(OH) groups to form Si(OK) species, thus reducing the number of surface silanol protons. Olefins, including low-carbon olefins and long-chain olefins, are important raw materials in the chemical industry [12,13]. Fischer-tropsch synthesis to olefins (FTO) refers to the catalytic conversion of CO and H2 into olefins via Fischer-Tropsch synthesis process [14,15]. This process has remarkable advantages such as a short process route and low energy consumption, indicating a promising development outlook [16,17]. Currently, highly effective catalytic systems for the FTO reaction primarily focus on the modification of Fe, Co, and Ru-based catalysts [18]. However, for Fe- and Co-based FTO catalysts, it is hard to avoid the water-gas shift reaction (WGSR), leading to a high proportion of CO2 byproducts (30 %∼50 %) and low efficiency for carbon utilization [19–21]. In contrast, Ru-based FTO catalysts exhibit lower CO2 selectivity and primarily generate long-chain olefins, with higher carbon utilization efficiency [22,23]. Additionally, during the FTO process, the catalytic performance can be tuned by the addition of electronic promoters such as sodium (Na) [24–27], potassium (K) [26], zirconium (Zr) [28,29], or zinc (Zn) [30]. Co-impregnation method has been widely applied to promote Ru-based FTO reactions. Given the significant influence of impregnation sequence on catalytic performance, the effects of sequential impregnation in Ru-based FTO reactions warrant thorough investigation. This work investigated the influence of impregnation sequences on the structure and performance of Ru-based FTO catalysts. Advanced characterization techniques including XRD, CO pulse chemisorption, TEM, XPS, FTIR, and in-situ CO-DRIFTS were employed to deepen insights into the relationship between the structural properties of the prepared catalysts and their catalytic behavior in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Chemicals Ruthenium nitrosyl nitrate solution (0.092 g Ru per gram of solution, Ltd, AR) was purchased from Peric (Ru(NO)(NO3)x(OH)y, x + y = 3). NaNO3 was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Aerosol silica (SiO2, AEROSIL 380) was purchased from Evonik Degussa China Co., Ltd. Deionized water was sourced from laboratory purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The catalysts were prepared using the incipient wetness impregnation method with different impregnation sequences. Ruthenium nitrosyl nitrate solution and NaNO3 (molar ratio of Na/Ru=0.5) were dissolved in deionized water to form a mixed salt solution. Aerosol silica was used as the catalyst support. 2.2.1 NaRu/SiO2 The catalyst was prepared by co-impregnation method. The mixture solution of ruthenium nitrosyl nitrate and alkali metal nitrate was used for the incipient wetness impregnation of SiO2. 2.2.2 Na-Ru/SiO2 The catalyst was prepared by stepwise impregnation. The solution containing Na was first impregnated onto the support, followed by a subsequent impregnation of the solution containing Ru onto the support. 2.2.3 Ru-Na/SiO2 The catalyst was prepared by stepwise impregnation. The solution containing Ru was first impregnated onto the support, followed by a subsequent impregnation of the solution containing Na onto the support. After each impregnation, the samples were dried at 60 °C for 4 h and calcined in air at 400 °C for 4 h. The loading amount of Ru and Na was kept at ca. 2.30 wt% and 0.29 wt%, respectively. The promoted Na-Ru/SiO2 catalysts with different Na content were prepared via a similar procedure with different amounts of NaNO3. Na-Ru/SiO2 samples with different Na/Ru ratios were denoted as x-Na-Ru/SiO2 (x = 0.25, 0.5 and 1.0), where x represents the Na/Ru molar ratio. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The actual metal content of the catalysts was determined using a Varian 710-ES Inductively Coupled Plasma Atomic Emission Spectrometer (ICP-OES, Optima 8000, PerkinElmer). Nitrogen adsorption measurements were conducted using a Micromeritics ASAP 2420 instrument. Before testing, 100 mg samples were degassed in a vacuum at 300 °C for 10 h. The specific surface area of the catalysts was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation, while the pore size was determined using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was performed using a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å), operating at 40 kV and 40 mA, with a scanning rate of 2 °/min from 5° to 90°. Phase analysis is obtained by comparing JCPDS standard cards. The crystallite size was calculated using the Scherrer equation. H2 temperature-programmed reaction (H2-TPR) experiments were tested on the Micromeritics ChemiSorb2920 instrument with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). A 50 mg sample was loaded into a U-type tube. Before TPR measurement, the samples were pretreated in He flow at 120 °C for 1 h, then cooled down to 50 °C. TCD signal started to record when the temperature was raised from 50 °C to 800 °C in 5 % H2/Ar (30 mL min−1) at a rate of 10 °C min−1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed with a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer XPS measurement. The standard C1s peak as a reference was located at 284.8 eV. CO chemisorption experiments were conducted using a Micromeritics Autochem-II 2920 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 100 mg catalyst was reduced under a hydrogen flow at 300 °C for 2 h, followed by the introduction of helium for 30 minutes to cool down to 50 °C. Subsequently, He flow was switched to 10 % CO/He until achieving saturated adsorption of CO to record the chemisorption isotherms. The dispersion of Ru was calculated by assuming a stoichiometric ratio of CO/Ru of 1:1. The FTIR spectrogram was carried out on a 32ThermoFisher Scientific FTIR spectrometer (Nicolet iS10) with a measurement range of 400–2000 cm−1. A background spectrum was collected before the analysis, and subsequently, the infrared spectrum of the sample was acquired. In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (in situ DRIFTS) of CO adsorption were conducted on a ThermoFisher Scientific FTIR spectrometer (Nicolet iS50). The sample was placed in an in-situ reaction cell. Before testing, the samples were reduced by H2 at 400 °C for 2 h. Afterward, the flow was switched to Ar to cool down to 50 °C, and a background spectrum was collected once the baseline was stabilized. Subsequently, the flow was switched from Ar to CO for adsorption for 30 minutes, followed by a 30-minute purge with Ar. DRIFT spectra were then collected. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-solution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) measurements were conducted on FEI Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN equipment with 200 kV accelerating voltage. The concentration of solid suspensions for TEM and HRTEM analysis was about 10 μg/mL. After reduction, the catalysts were cooled with helium gas and then passivated with a 1 vol% O2/Ar mixture for 1 h at room temperature for further structure characterization. For the spent catalysts, residual wax on the surface was removed by washing with CS2, followed by air-drying in a fume hood. 2.4 Catalytic evaluation CO hydrogenation reaction was tested in a stainless steel fixed-bed reactor. 1.0 g catalyst (40–60 mesh) diluted with 3.0 g same-size silica was loaded into the reactor. Before catalytic testing, the samples were reduced in pure H2 at 400 °C with a heating ramp of 2 °C/min for 4 h at 1 bar with weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 8000 mL·g−1·h−1. After reduction, the reactor was cooled down to the desired temperature, and the gas feedstock was switched to feed gas with H2/CO= 2 (H2/CO/N2=64.7/32.3/3, N2 as an internal standard), then the pressure was controlled to 10 bar. The reaction temperature was increased to 260 °C with WHSV of 3000 mL·g−1·h−1. The outlet gas compositions were analyzed using an online gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890B) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID). After 10 h of reaction, a relatively steady-state operation was reached. The data for catalytic performance was collected after 24 h of steady-state operation. The liquid products were collected and analyzed by off-line Agilent GC. The obtained carbon balance, oxygen balance, and mass balance were all within the range of 95–105 %. CO conversion was calculated according to the following Eq. (1): (1) CO Conversion = C O inlet − C O outlet C O inlet × 100 % Where COinlet and COoutlet represent moles of CO at the inlet and the outlet, respectively. CO2 selectivity was calculated according to the following Eq. (2): (2) CO 2 selectivity = C O 2 outlet C O inlet − C O outlet × 100 % where CO2 outlet denotes moles of CO2 at the outlet. The selectivity of individual products (hydrocarbons or oxygenates) was obtained according to the following Eqs. (3) and (4): (3) Hydrocarbons Selectivity = Carbon moles in hydrocarbons Total carbon moles in all products × 100 % (4) Oxygenates Selectivity = Carbon moles in oxygenates Total carbon moles in all products × 100 % The reaction rate was calculated as the following Eq. (5): (5) Reaction rate CO = WHSV × X CO × CO Concentration 22400 × ξ Ru Where WHSV is the weight hourly space velocity, CO Concentration represents the molar concentration of CO in the feedstock, XCO is the CO conversion, ξRu represents the actual loading of Ru measured by ICP-AES. STYolefins was calculated as the following Eq. (6): (6) STY olefins = m olefins ( m cat . × ξ Ru × M Ru ) × t Where molefins represents the mass of olefins produced over a certain period, mcat. represents the mass of the catalyst loaded in the reaction vessel, and MRu is the relative atomic mass of Ru (101.07 g/mol). The turnover frequency (TOF) value was calculated as follows: (7) TOF = Reaction rate CO × M Ru D Ru × 3600 Where MRu is the relative atomic mass of Ru (101.07 g/mol), DRu is the dispersion of metallic Ru measured by CO chemisorption. The chain growth probability (α) was calculated according to Anderson-Schulz-Flory distribution: (8) ( W n n ) = ( 1 − α ) 2 α ( n − 1 ) Where Wn represents the mass fraction of product, n represents the carbon number of product. The apparent activation energy (Ea) was measured by changing the reaction temperature. In addition, the results of Ea were all determined at CO conversion range of 2–10 %. (9) k = A × e − E a / RT Where k is the rate constant, R is 8.314, T is the thermodynamic temperature, Ea is the apparent activation energy, and A is the pre-index factor (also known as the frequency factor). The cumulative olefins selectivity was calculated as the following Eq. (10). (10) CTotal ==C2 =+C3 =+…+Cn = (n ≥ 2) Where the n is the carbon number of olefins. 3 Results 3.1 Structure properties of catalysts The specific surface area of various RuNa catalysts was determined using N2 physisorption. As shown in Table 1, NaRu/SiO2 exhibited a specific surface area of 262 m2/g, while Na-Ru/SiO2 and Ru-Na/SiO2 had specific surface areas of 271 m2/g and 281 m2/g, respectively. Compared to the specific surface area of the sole SiO2 support, the specific surface area of various catalysts showed a slight decrease. The average pore diameters were 20.9 nm for NaRu/SiO2, 19.6 nm for Ru-Na/SiO2, and 20.2 nm for Na-Ru/SiO2, respectively, indicating that the catalysts fall within the mesoporous range, with an increase in pore diameter compared to the support (17.5 nm). According to the pore size distribution, similar pore size distribution was found for the catalysts prepared with different impregnation sequences, which was consistent with the trend of average pore size (Figure S1). The pore volume was approximately 1.4 cm3/g for all samples, showing little variation. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for each catalyst were shown in Fig. 1a. According to the IUPAC classification, all of the studied catalysts exhibited typical type IV adsorption isotherm, indicating that changing the impregnation sequence did not significantly alter the pore structure. The actual loading amount of Ru and Na for various catalysts was determined by ICP-OES. The loading of Ru and Na in various samples was nearly identical at approximately 2.30 wt% and 0.29 wt%, respectively, and the actual Na/Ru molar ratio closely matched the nominal composition as shown in Table S1. The phase composition of various calcined, reduced, and spent catalysts was analyzed using X-ray diffraction (XRD), as shown in Fig. 1b – 1d. For all of the calcined samples, similar XRD patterns were observed, and RuO2 phase was exclusively detected. After H2 reduction, RuO2 was reduced to metallic Ru0. As for the spent catalysts, the metallic Ru0 phase was exclusively detected. The results indicate that no significant phase change was observed among the catalysts prepared via different impregnation sequences. The average crystallite size of Ru species for various samples was calculated and shown in Table S2. It was found that after calcination, the particle size of the samples decreased from 15 (Ru-Na/SiO2) to about 9 nm (NaRu/SiO2 and Na-Ru/SiO2). After reduction, the particle size for Ru-Na/SiO2 was about 10 nm, while it decreased to about 6 nm for NaRu/SiO2 and Na-Ru/SiO2. These results suggested that NaRu/SiO2 and Na-Ru/SiO2 catalysts exhibited smaller particle sizes after calcination, reduction, and reaction, while the Ru-Na/SiO2 catalysts exhibited larger particle sizes, indicating higher Ru dispersion for Na-Ru/SiO2 and NaRu/SiO2. The dispersion of Ru was further investigated by CO chemisorption ( Fig. 2a). It can be observed that the dispersion of Ru can be significantly influenced by altering the impregnation sequences. The Ru dispersion in Na-Ru/SiO2 is the highest (7.4 %). This indicated that when Na is firstly impregnated before Ru, the dispersion of Ru can be effectively improved, which is consistent with the results of particle size distribution analysis from XRD. H2-TPR profiles were plotted and shown in Fig. 2b. All catalysts exhibited a distinct reduction peak, and it can be attributed to the reduction of RuO2 to metallic Ru0. The catalysts of Ru-Na/SiO2 showed a higher reduction temperature around 161 °C. Compared with Ru-Na/SiO2 catalyst, both Na-Ru/SiO2 and NaRu/SiO2 catalysts showed a lower reduction temperature (144 °C and 153 °C, respectively) [31]. Fig. 3 showed the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results of various catalysts at different stages. The C 1 s and Ru 3d spectra are presented simultaneously, with charge calibration performed using the C 1 s peak at BE = 284.8 eV. For the calcined catalysts, the XPS peaks at BE = 280.8–280.9 eV corresponded to RuO2 species [32]. For the reduced catalysts, the XPS peaks at BE = 280.3–280.5 eV corresponded to the surface Ru0 species [33,34]. The BE value for Na-Ru/SiO2 catalyst was lower obviously than Ru-Na/SiO2. A shift of the BE value for Ru0 species in the Na-Ru/SiO2 catalyst towards lower binding energies indicates that Na has a stronger ability to transfer electrons to Ru when Na was introduced before Ru. The transfer of electrons from Na to Ru increased the electron cloud density around Ru. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the reduced various samples with different impregnation sequences were displayed in Fig. 4. For all of the catalysts studied, metallic Ru0 nanoparticles were approximately spherical [35]. However, it can be seen that Ru nanoparticles were easier to aggregate for the Ru-Na/SiO2 catalyst. Under identical scaling conditions, Ru-Na/SiO2 exhibited large Ru particles with particle sizes around 6.6 nm, prone to clustering and poor dispersion. In contrast, Ru was more uniformly dispersed on SiO2 and appeared as small particles over Na-Ru/SiO2 and NaRu/SiO2 samples. Both NaRu/SiO2 and Na-Ru/SiO2 catalysts exhibited lower particle sizes of approximately 3.8 nm and 4.0 nm, respectively. Representative TEM images of the spent catalysts were also presented in Figure S2. The Ru-Na/SiO2 spent catalyst had a larger Ru nanoparticle size (6.8 nm), and the change trend of size for the spent catalysts was consistent with that of reduced samples. The surface of SiO2 typically contains a substantial concentration of Si-OH groups, and the anchoring of active components onto the catalyst generally requires interactions between the active species and the Si-OH groups on the surface. Infrared absorption tests were conducted on various catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5, all catalysts with varying impregnation sequences exhibited absorption peaks at 1096 cm−1 and 970 cm−1. The peak at 1096 cm−1 corresponded to the Si-O-Si bond, while the peak at 970 cm−1 was attributed to Si-OH groups [36–38]. The ratio of the peak area at 970 cm−1 (Area1) to the peak area at 1096 cm−1 (Area2) was calculated to study the relative concentration of Si-OH. The relative peak area ratios are ordered as follows: Na-Ru/SiO2 > NaRu/SiO2 > Ru-Na/SiO2 (Fig. 5b and Table 2). Obviously, the Si-OH content was more abundant in the case of the NaRu/SiO2 and Na-Ru/SiO2. Conversely, the Ru-Na/SiO2 catalyst showed the lowest hydroxyl group content on its surface. 3.2 Catalytic performance The evaluation of Ru-based catalysts for CO hydrogenation is illustrated in Fig. 6a. The catalytic performance was greatly influenced by the impregnation sequence. Both NaRu/SiO2 and Na-Ru/SiO2 catalysts exhibit higher CO conversion, reaction rates, and olefins selectivity than Ru-Na/SiO2. For example, Na-Ru/SiO2 catalyst showed a CO conversion of 43.5 % and total olefin selectivity of 77.9 %. In contrast, Ru-Na/SiO2 catalyst demonstrated lower CO conversion (26.6 %) and total olefin selectivity (74.3 %). In addition, similar intrinsic activity was found for the three catalysts with similar TOFs about 0.28 s−1. However, the comparison of olefins STY (olefins space-time yield) (Fig. 6b) showed that Na-Ru/SiO2 presented the highest yield for olefins with STY of 696.9 g·molRu −1·h−1, while the STY was only 341.6 g·molRu −1·h−1 for Ru-Na/SiO2. The results indicated that the Na-Ru/SiO2 catalyst greatly improved the utilization of the precious metal Ru by a factor of two compared with Ru-Na/SiO2. Fig. 7 illustrates the olefin-to-paraffin (O/P) ratio and hydrocarbon distribution for various catalysts. As shown in Fig. 7a, the O/P ratio followed the order: NaRu/SiO2≈Na-Ru/SiO2>Ru-Na/SiO2. The chain growth probability (α) of the hydrocarbons was also calculated, showing that the chain growth factor for Ru-Na/SiO2 was the lowest (0.71). The chain growth factors for NaRu/SiO2 and Na-Ru/SiO2 catalysts were 0.78 and 0.73, respectively. In addition, we also compared the α of olefins in catalysts with different impregnation sequences and found that the trend of change was consistent with that of hydrocarbon products (Figure S3). Additionally, Fig. 7b - 7d provided detailed proportions of hydrocarbons. For each catalyst studied, olefins were the main component of the total hydrocarbons. Due to the best FTO performance over Na-Ru/SiO2 catalyst, the stability of Na-Ru/SiO2 was also tested (Figure S4). An increase in CO conversion was observed in the initial stage followed by stabilization, during which no significant decline in performance was observed, indicating promising stability. Since Na played a key role in Ru-based FTO reaction, we also investigated the influence of Na/Ru molar ratios on catalytic performance of Na-Ru/SiO2, as shown in Fig. 8. According to the hydrocarbon product distribution, 98 % of the hydrocarbons were categorized within the C20 range. As the Na/Ru molar ratio increased, CO conversion gradually decreased. However, when the Na/Ru molar ratio increased from 0.25 to 1, the total olefins selectivity increased from 76.8 % to 78.7 %, and then slightly decreased to 77.6 %. Additionally, when the Na/Ru molar ratio was 0.25, the highest CO conversion and chain growth factor (α) were obtained. The effect of reaction conditions on the catalytic performance of Na-Ru/SiO2 was thoroughly investigated. The influence of reaction temperatures was first studied. It was revealed that as the reaction temperature increased, CO conversion exhibited a gradual upward trend. The products predominantly consisted of olefins in the 240–270 °C range, with the highest olefin selectivity observed at 260 °C (Figure S5a). Besides, the olefin product distribution and olefin-to-paraffin ratio of the Na-Ru/SiO2 catalyst showed that, with increasing temperature, the proportion of lower olefins and long-chain olefins remained relatively stable, with C5+ = selectivity around 70 %. The O/P ratio reached the highest at 260 °C (Figure S5b and Table S3). Besides, it was found that the chain growth factor (α) displayed minimal variation at different temperatures. The cumulative olefins selectivity demonstrated that most of the obtained olefins were in the range of C2-C20, confirming a concentrated distribution of olefins. Furthermore, the impact of reaction pressures (5–30 bar) on catalytic performance was investigated. As the reaction pressure increased, CO conversion significantly increased. In terms of product distribution, at low pressure (5 bar), the selectivity to CH4 and CO2 was relatively high, with the total selectivity for C1 by-products close to 10 %, and the oxygenate selectivity was only 1.3 %. As the reaction pressure increased to 10 bar, the selectivity for C1 by-products notably decreased, and the olefins selectivity increased from 72.1 % to 77.9 %. With the further increase of reaction pressure to 30 bar, the olefins selectivity decreased (Figure S6a). The O/P ratios for different carbon numbers also indicated that the O/P ratio at low pressure was significantly higher than that at high pressure, which corresponds with the trend in olefins selectivity (Figure S6b and Table S4). Comparing the olefins distribution, it revealed that as the reaction pressure increased, the proportion of lower olefins decreased from 51.0 % to 17.7 %, while the corresponding proportion of long-chain olefins increased from 49.0 % to 82.3 % (Figure S6c - 6f). The influence of varying space velocities on catalytic performance was investigated (1500–9000 mL·g−1·h−1). As space velocity increased, CO conversion gradually decreased from 61.2 % to 9.8 %, while the selectivity for C1 byproducts and olefins remained almost stable, and olefins selectivity was all above 76.0 % (Figure S7). Furthermore, the α value for hydrocarbons gradually decreased with increasing space velocities. The cumulative olefins selectivity also indicated that the majority of the olefins were in the range of C2 to C20 (Figure S7c - 7f). 4 Discussion In-situ DRIFTS spectra was used to investigate the mechanism for the difference in FTO performance over various catalysts by different impregnation sequences. As shown in Fig. 9a, all catalysts exhibited three types of CO chemisorption on the metal Ru surface. The peak range of 2000–2050 cm−1 corresponded to the typical linear adsorption of CO, while the peak around 1966 cm−1 corresponded to CO adsorbed in a formatted configuration, and the peak around 1811 cm−1 indicated CO in a bridged configuration [39]. Analysis of the peak positions revealed that NaRu/SiO2 and Na-Ru/SiO2 exhibit a red shift in the linear CO adsorption peak towards lower wavenumbers, suggesting enhanced CO adsorption capacity for Na-Ru/SiO2 and NaRu/SiO2. Fig. 9b illustrated the apparent activation energy for CO hydrogenation on various catalysts. The apparent activation energy (Ea) values for all catalysts were approximately 70–75 kJ/mol. The similar apparent activation energy indicated that the CO dissociation ability was not affected by impregnation sequences of Na and Ru. The above results indicated that different impregnation sequences have a significant impact on the catalytic performance of Ru-based FTO catalysts. In the previous study, active metal components were typically supported on oxide materials such as Al2O3, SiO2, and zeolites [40–43]. Adjusting the isoelectric point (IEP) of the support can alter the dispersion and performance of active metals in the catalyst, thereby affecting catalytic efficiency. In this work, after initially impregnating sodium (Na) onto the support surface, the surface will become alkaline, leading to a higher concentration of negative charge [44]. This alteration in surface charge is crucial for the following subsequent deposition of ruthenium (Ru). When Ru is further impregnated onto the Na/SiO2 support, the negatively-charged surface facilitates a better distribution of the positively-charged Ru species, resulting in higher dispersion of Ru nanoparticles after reduction. Obviously, the sequence of impregnation plays a critical role in determining the dispersion of metal particles on a support. By controlling the surface charge through the initial impregnation of Na, it is possible to optimize the dispersion of the subsequent active components on the support, which exhibits significant implication for the catalytic performance of catalysts. 5 Conclusion In summary, our study meticulously examined the influence of different impregnation sequences on the structural characteristics and catalytic performance of RuNa catalysts for FTO reaction. Our findings underscore the profound influence of the impregnation sequence on the catalyst's efficiency. Most notably, the Na-Ru/SiO2 catalyst, which involved the impregnation of Na before Ru, demonstrated superior performance with the highest CO conversion rate of 43.5 % and impressive olefins yield of 33.9 %. This particular sequential impregnation strategy was found to significantly enhance the catalyst's efficacy in the FTO reaction. Comprehensive characterizations, including XRD, H2-TPR, TEM, and other advanced techniques, were employed to elucidate the structural properties of the catalysts. These analyses revealed that the Na-Ru/SiO2 catalyst exhibited an enhanced dispersion of Ru nanoparticles, which facilitated the exposure of more active sites for the FTO reaction. Additionally, XPS analysis provided insights into the electronic structure of the catalysts. It indicated a notable increase in the electron density at the Ru center within the Na-Ru/SiO2 catalyst. This enhancement in electron density is believed to have boosted the CO adsorption capacity, which is a critical step in the FTO reaction. As a result, catalytic activity was increased, leading to a higher production of olefins. Our research findings demonstrate that the performance of Ru-based catalysts can be significantly optimized by carefully tailoring the impregnation sequence. This strategy not only offers a straightforward approach but also presents an effective method for the design and development of highly efficient Ru-based catalysts for the FTO process. This discovery could have significant implications for the optimization of FTO catalysts in industrial applications, potentially leading to more sustainable and cost-effective production of olefins from syngas. coredata.dc:description: The influence of impregnation sequences on the structure and performance of the Ru-based catalysts for olefins synthesis from syngas via Fischer-Tropsch reaction (FTO) was investigated. Among the catalysts studied, Na-Ru/SiO2 (Na was impregnated before Ru) exhibited the highest CO conversion (43.5 %) and olefins yield (33.9 %). In contrast, Ru-Na/SiO2 (Ru was impregnated before Na) showed the lowest CO conversion (26.6 %) and olefins yield (19.8 %). Characterization analysis indicated that Na-Ru/SiO2 exhibited higher Ru dispersion. In addition, the structural configuration of Na-Ru/SiO2 was found to enhance CO adsorption capabilities to create a C*-rich localized chemical environment, thereby increasing catalytic activity and olefins production. This study demonstrates a straightforward and effective approach to optimize Ru utilization for the design of Ru-based FTO catalysts.
